For calculating the force on the ions we need to provide the areal density $\sigma$ of the electron layer. In order to place a layer of particles in front of the mirror and still allow a standing wave to form upon incidence of a laser wave, the thin layer needs to transmit radiation in the relevant frequency regime. The electrons will however, upon incidence of the laser, be accelerated to form a current $j$ emitting radiation canceling the incoming one. Since the current per unit area is limited by $j_{\text{max}} = e \sigma c$ intensities higher than $I_{\text{th}} = c/\left(4\pi\right)\times\left(2\pi j_{\text{max}}/c\right)^2 = \pi c e^2 \sigma^2$ cannot be canceled and are transmitted through the layer. This is a simple particular case of relativistic self-induced transparency (RSIT) \cite{Vshivkov_etal_1998,Macchi_etal_2009}, as applied in the break-out afterburner \cite{Yin_etal_2006,Hegelich_etal_2006,Jung_etal_2013a,Jung_etal_2013b,Hegelich_etal_2013}. In dimensionless units, a radiation field of amplitude $a_0 = eE_0/m_e c\omega_0 $ is transmitted trough a plasma layer with areal density below the threshold $\sigma_0 = \sigma_\text{cr}a_0/\pi$, where $\sigma_\text{cr}=2\pi c n_\text{cr}/\omega_0 $ with the critical plasma density $n_\text{cr} = m_e\omega_0^2/4\pi e^2$. The Coulomb attraction to the residual ions of the layer dominates over the light pressure force $F_l = (2/c)I$, until a laser of intensity $I$ reaches the threshold value $I_{\text{th}}$. Thus, almost immediately after starting traveling beyond the layer, the electrons get trapped by the newly established standing wave, making this scheme stable against the loss of electrons due to radiation pressure into the mirror. Unlike in the staged ion acceleration scheme, driven by a subsequent ponderomotive shift of the electrons \cite{gonoskov.prl.2009}, the electrons are here locked in the resulting standing wave.

Given that the amplitude $a_0$ of the laser is a function of time, the laser will be transmitted through the thin layer only during the time interval $\tau_\text{acc}$ defined by $a_0(\tau_\text{acc}/2) = \pi \sigma /\sigma_\text{cr}$, (assuming the laser's peak to be located at $t\equiv0$), i.e., while the thin layer is relativistically transparent. We assume the electron layer to be confined by the laser field throughout this whole time interval whence the ions will be accelerated by a constant acceleration field approximately given by Eq.~(\ref{Eq:CoulombForce}) for a time $\tau_\text{acc}$. We see that the ions obtain relativistic energies for $a_0\left(1+{\mathcal{C}}^2\right)^{1/4}\gtrsim m_p\Delta\omega_0/4m_e\omega_0$. State-of-art laser facility are capable of achieving octave-spanning bandwidths. For the conservative estimate $\Delta\omega_0 \approx 0.4 \omega_0$ and realistic chirps ${\mathcal{C}} \lesssim 10^2$ the ions will acquire relativistic energies for $a_0 \lesssim m_p/100 m_e$, i.e., for much lower field intensities than would naively have been expected from the definition of the relativistic field strength of the laser. From Eq.~(\ref{Eq:OptimalMomentum}) we can additionally read off that the ions' optimum kinetic momentum will scale as $p_\text{ion}^\text{opt}\sim \left(1+{\mathcal{C}}^2\right)^{1/4}$, i.e., grow with increasing pulse chirp, provided one can keep the ions trapped behind the electron layer through the whole pulse duration. A natural upper limit for the chirp, however, is reached when the chirped laser pulse is no longer relativistic and there is no RSIT. At the same time, increasing the chirp requires a reduced charge surface density, according to $\sigma \sim {\left(1+{\mathcal{C}}^2\right)^{-1/4}}$, reducing the number of accelerated particles. The areal charge current density $j=\sigma p_\text{ion}^\text{opt}/m \sim a_0^2$ is thus independent of the chirp. We conclude that, provided one is able to maintain the optimum surface density condition, the pulse chirp is a tunable parameter to trade maximum particle energies for number of accelerated particles.

The above derived ion momentum was optimized merely by tuning the thickness of the thin plasma layer in front of the reflecting mirror. It is thus independent of the electron layer velocity, as dictated by the propagation speed of the field nodes according to Eq.~(\ref{Eq:NodeVelocity}), as long as it can be ensured that the ions feel the accelerating field over the full time interval $\tau_\text{acc}$. It will, however, be favorable to optimize the laser pulse chirp in order that the electron layer is not accelerated too quickly, since this would detach it from the accelerated ion layer. In order to estimate this optimal laser chirp we note that for nonrelativistic ions of mass $m_\text{ion}$ the derived peak ion momentum corresponds to a final ion velocity $v_\text{ion} \approx p^\text{opt}_\text{ion}/m_\text{ion}$. In order for the ions not to be left behind by the accelerated electron layer, this final velocity should be equal to the node velocity given by Eq.~(\ref{Eq:NodeVelocity}). Since this expression is time-dependent, we evaluate it at the FWHM time duration of the pulse, which is approximately the time when the ions should approach their final velocity. The corresponding equation has two solutions for ${\mathcal{C}} \ll 1$ and ${\mathcal{C}}\gg1$. However, in order to access the full frequency spectrum of the pulse, we have to choose the latter case. Considering in addition $\Delta\omega_0\lesssim \omega_0$ we can find a simplified optimal chirp condition to be given by

The scaling ${\mathcal{C}}^\text{opt}\sim a_0^{-2/3}$ is understood by the ions achieving higher final energies for higher pulse energies and thus higher velocities.

In order to test the above analytical predictions we performed a numerical experiment in form of a particle-in-cell (PIC) simulation. As the process is essentially one-dimensional and not susceptible to transverse instabilities we content ourselves with a 1D PIC simulation with 16000 cells, in a simulation box of approximately 30 $\mu$m size, using the code PICADOR \cite{PicadorTeam}. Higher dimensional effects do not affect the propagation speed of the standing wave nodes, which is the limiting factor for the ion acceleration. The experimental setup is a circularly polarized laser pulse of central wavelength $\lambda_0 = 800$ nm under normal incidence, focused to a $5\, \mu$m spot on the surface of the reflecting mirror, placed at $x=0$. In front of the heavy mirror we place a thin layer of electrons and protons (mass $m_p$ and charge $-e$) at $x=\lambda_0/2$, representing the plasma layer to be accelerated. Such a configuration can be realized by mounting a fine mesh on a high density target (mirror) and covering the mesh with a thin foil (accelerated layer, see Fig.~\ref{fig:Setup}). The pulse's electric field is modeled by Eq.~(\ref{Eq:ChirpedField}). We choose the initial conditions such that at the simulation start the center of the chirped laser pulse is placed approximately $5$ times its spatial width in front of the layer.

In a first example we demonstrate that CSWA can provide a highly efficient and robust acceleration mechanism (see Supplementary video and Fig.~\ref{fig:PhaseSpace}, parameters in the caption). First the incident laser radiation is reflected by the layer, causing a minor internal shift of the layer's electrons and a subsequent ion acceleration in positive $x$-direction. Surpassing the threshold intensity ($t \approx 20$~fs), the incident radiation starts to penetrate the layer, forms a standing wave in front of the mirror and captures the electrons within only $1$~fs. They follow the field node and the generated quasi-static longitudinal field starts to accelerate ions in the negative $x$-direction ($t \approx 22-40$~fs). The acceleration continues even after the laser radiation has decoupled from the electron layer with the standing wave provided by a mode of radiation locked between the layer and the mirror ($t \approx 44-60$~fs), accelerating the ions to energies of about $100$ MeV. While this second stage may be susceptible to plasma instabilities, similar to the light sail mechanism, the ions gaining high energies during the first stage leads to significantly improved conditions for energy gain before the formation of such instabilities. The ions are also strongly confined in energy as well as position, showing that CSWA could produce highly monochromatic and collimated ion beams. 

Next, in order to highlight wide applicability range and tunability through the chirp, we performed a parameter scan varying the total pulse energy $\varepsilon_0$, connected with the dimensionless amplitude via $a_0\sim\sqrt{\varepsilon_0}$ and the chirp $\mathcal{C}$ (see Fig.~\ref{fig:ParameterScan}). The laser peak intensity depends on these parameters as $I_0 \sim \varepsilon_0/\sqrt{(1+\mathcal{C}^2)}$. Comparing the results to Eq.~(\ref{Eq:OptimalMomentum}) we find good agreement with the theoretical predictions with only a small island of poor acceleration efficiency around pulse chirps of $\mathcal{C}\approx-5$ and small pulse energies. Clearly visible is the decrease of the optimal chirp for highest ion energies with increasing pulse energy, i.e., increasing $a_0$, as predicted by Eq.~(\ref{Eq:OptimalChirp}). CSWA is demonstrated to produce (nonrelativistic) ion energies of order $\varepsilon_\text{ion} =p_\text{ion}^2/2m_p \sim 100$ MeV for pulse energies $\varepsilon_0\sim10$ J. Eq.~(\ref{Eq:OptimalMomentum}) indicates that scaling to $100$ J of the CSWA, it should be possible to reach dense and collimated ion beams of energies up to $\varepsilon_\text{ion} \sim \varepsilon_0 \sim 1$ GeV.

The number of particles accelerated is estimated by observing that almost all particles of the thin layer are accelerated (see Fig.~\ref{fig:PhaseSpace} (c)). A good estimate for the total number of particles will then be the areal charge density multiplied with the laser spot size, resulting for the example of Fig.~\ref{fig:PhaseSpace} in an estimate $N\approx 3\times10^{11}$, corresponding to a charge in the nC range.

In summary we have presented and analyzed a novel approach to laser ion acceleration making use of a very direct conversion mechanism of a transverse laser field into an accelerating field while at the same time being less susceptible to the formation of plasma instabilities. We demonstrated its feasibility over a wide parameter range, from currently existing facilities to upcoming ones, and presented a scaling law indicating the feasibility of GeV-level ion acceleration at upcoming facilities.

We see that the ions obtain relativistic energies for $a_0\left(1+{\mathcal{C}}^2\right)^{1/4}\gtrsim m_p\Delta\omega_0/4m_e\omega_0$. State-of-art laser facility are capable of achieving octave-spanning bandwidths. For the conservative estimate $\Delta\omega_0 \approx 0.4 \omega_0$ and realistic chirps ${\mathcal{C}} \lesssim 10^2$ the ions will acquire relativistic energies for $a_0 \lesssim m_p/100 m_e$, i.e., for much lower field intensities than would naively have been expected from the definition of the relativistic field strength of the laser. From Eq.~(\ref{Eq:OptimalMomentum}) we can additionally read off that the ions' optimum kinetic momentum will scale as $p_\text{ion}^\text{opt}\sim \left(1+{\mathcal{C}}^2\right)^{1/4}$, i.e., grow with increasing pulse chirp, provided one can keep the ions trapped behind the electron layer through the whole pulse duration. A natural upper limit for the chirp, however, is reached when the chirped laser pulse is no longer relativistic and there is no RSIT. At the same time, increasing the chirp requires a reduced charge surface density, according to $\sigma \sim {\left(1+{\mathcal{C}}^2\right)^{-1/4}}$, reducing the number of accelerated particles. The areal charge current density $j=\sigma p_\text{ion}^\text{opt}/m \sim a_0^2$ is thus independent of the chirp. We conclude that, provided one is able to maintain the optimum surface density condition, the pulse chirp is a tunable parameter to trade maximum particle energies for number of accelerated particles.

The above derived ion momentum was optimized merely by tuning the thickness of the thin plasma layer in front of the reflecting mirror. It is thus independent of the electron layer velocity, as dictated by the propagation speed of the field nodes according to Eq.~(\ref{Eq:NodeVelocity}), as long as it can be ensured that the ions feel the accelerating field over the full time interval $\tau_\text{acc}$.
